column2: Kusanagi

Part of the Imperial Regalia of Japan, the sword Kusanagi no Tsurugi ("The Grass Cutting Sword"), sometimes known as Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi ("The Heavenly Sword of Gathering Clouds"), is said to represent the virtue of valor.
Yata no Kagami
Part of the Imperial Regalia of Japan, the sacred mirror Yata no Kagami ("The Eight Hand Mirror") represents the virtue of wisdom and honesty.
Yasakani no Magatama
Part of the Imperial Regalia of Japan, the jewel Yasakani no Magatama has unknown, but indisputably sacred, properties.
Heirloom Seal of the Realm
Carved out of the famed jade disc He Shi Bi, the Heirloom Seal of the Realm is a symbol of the Mandate of Heaven itself.
King of Na Gold Seal
Gifted to "the King the Na state of the Wa" by the Han Dynasty, this seal potentially denotes vassalage to China.
Five stars rising in the East
This ancient Chinese arm protector carries the inscription "Five stars rising in the east benefit China", possibly alluding to a phrase in the Records of the Grand Historian.
Put down South Qiang
This ancient Chinese arm protector carries the inscription "Put down South Qiang".
Flying Horse
This bronze sculpture of a horse balanced on one hoof atop a flying swallow is truly impressive.
Qin Bronze Chariot
This long-buried bronze chariot is truly a magnificent representation of the strength of a Chinese dynasty long gone.
Silk painting of a man riding a dragon
This painting depicts a man riding a dragon. Judging by his appearance and various aspects of the painting, he is most likely a noble of some kind.
Sakyamuni Preaching
This embroidery depicts the Buddha preaching the Lotus Sutra atop Gridhraj Parvat.
Twelve Metal Colossi
Forged by Qin Shi Huangdi from the weapons of his foes, the nine surviving colossi are an imposing and majestic sight to behold.
Nine Tripod Cauldrons
Supposedly cast by Yu the Great of Xia, these cauldrons symbolize the power and authority of the ruling dynasty.
Houmuwu ding
This heavy bronze ding is richly decorated and has been inscribed with the temple name of Fu Jing, a queen of Wu Ding.
Taima Mandala
This detailed mandala was supposedly created in the presence of Chujo-hime by two nuns that some suspect were Amida and Kannon in disguise.
Tenjukoku Shucho Mandala
Created in honor of Prince Shotoku, one of the earliest proponents of Buddhism in Japan, this mandala is both old and beautiful.
Shaka rising from the Gold Coffin
Depicting the resurrection of the Shakyamuni Buddha, this masterpiece was created by an unknown but extremely skiled artist.
Murasaki Shikibu Nikki Emaki
This picture scroll contains illustrations inspired by the diary of Murasaki Shikibu, the author of the Tale of Genji.
Nishi-Honganji Sanju-rokunin-kashu
This illuminated manuscript contains a collection of waka poetry by the Thirty-Six Immortals of Poetry.
Jigokuzoji
The "Hell Scroll" depicts seven of the sixteen lesser hells presented in the Kisekyo (the "Sutra of the World Arising").
Genji Monogatari Emaki
This picture scrll contains illustrations from The Tale of Genji, written by Murasaki Shikibu.
Extermination of Evil
This set of five paintings depicts several traditional Asian deities banishing evil.
Sugari no Ontachi
The sword Sugari no Ontachi is normally kept at the Ise Grand Shrine.
Gilt-bronze Maitreya in Meditation
This statue of the Maitreya, the future Buddha, is a masterpiece created in either Baekje or Silla.
Gilt-bronze Maitreya in Meditation
This statue of the Maitreya, the future Buddha, is a masterpiece created in Silla.
Gilt-bronze Incense Burner of Baekje
This incense burner incorporates both Buddhist and Taoist themeas, as well as some that might not belong to either.
The Seven-Branched Sword
The Seven-Branched Sword was a gift from the King of Baekje to the Emperor of Japan, and a description of its origin is inscribed on the blade itself.
Ngoc Lu drum
This drum is believed to have been created in ancient times by the Lac Viet people and is decorated with depictions of people and animals.
Cura Si Manjakini
The sword Cura Si Manjakini is a symbol of rightful sovereignty and power in Malay culture.
Preah Khan Reach
Gifted to Jayavarman III by his father Jayavarman II, this sword signifies the authority of the Khmer monarch.
Book of Etiquette and Ceremonial
Describing social behavior and ceremonial ritual during the Spring and Autumn period, this is one of the oldest works of chinese literature.
I Ching
Sometimes called the Book of Changes, the I Ching is an ancient book of divination.
Guoyu
Also known as the Discourse of the States, this book contains speeches from the Spring and Autumn period.
Spring and Autumn Annals
Supposedly compiled by Confucius himself, this is one of the Five Classics of Chinese literature.
Mozi
This books speaks higly of Mohist ideals such as impartiality, meritocratic governance, economic growth, and aversion to ostentation.
Wuzi
Attributed to Wu Qi, this book covers various military matters, putting a special emphasis on logistics and preparation.
Thirty-Six Stratagems
This book illustrates a number of stratagems useful in politics, war, and civil interaction, putting a special focus on cunning and deception.
Classic of Filial Piety
This text covers the topic of filial piety, and is supposedly based on a conversation between Confucius and his student Zengzi.
The Methods of the Sima
This military text covers a variety of topics, including laws, regulations, government policies, military organization, military administration, discipline, basic values, tactics, and strategy.
Book of Lord Shang
Named after Shang Yang, minister to Duke Xiao of Qin, this book focuses on legalistic considerations such as the value of impartial laws.
Wei Liaozi
This book advocates for a government based on humanistic values... but also for harsh punishments for heterodoxy.
Tao Te Ching
Credited to Laozi, this text has inspired a variety of Chinese philosophies and religions, especially Taoism.
Sun Bin's Art of War
Written by Sun Bin, a supposed descendant of Sun Tzu, this work was thought to have been lost around the end of the Eastern Han dynasty.
Lost Book of Zhou
This compilation of historical documents related to Western Zhou is of somewhat questionable validity, but could perhaps be of use to some readers.
Book of Rites
Considered a central part of the Confucian canon, this text describes the social forms, administration, and ceremonial rites of the Zhou dynasty.
The Commentary of Zuo
Attributed to Zuo Qiuming, this commnetary on the Spring and Autumn Annals is the origin of many Chinese sayings and idioms.
Book of Documents
Preserved from Qin Shi Huang's burning of books and burying of scholars by Fu Sheng, this book of political philosophy contains rhetorical prose attributed to many ancient figues.
Book of Documents
Discovered in the walls of his family's estate by Kong Anguo, this text is considered more authentic than the version saved by Fu Sheng.
Mencius
Written by Meng Ke, better known as Mencius, this book is a collection of interviews, anecdotes, and conversations.
Zhuangzi
This book contains allegories, fables, anecdotes, and parables, all meant to illustrate the falseness of human distinctions between good and bad, and the value of embracing Taoism.
Annals of the Warring States
This ancient text tells of political manipulation and warfare during the Warring States period.
Verses of Chu
This poetry anthology primarily contains poetry attributed to Qu Yuan and Song Yu, both from the Warring States period.
Lüshi Chunqiu
Also known as Master Lü's Spring and Autumn Annals, this work is both well organized and comprehesive, even covering subjects such as music and agriculture.
Xunzi
Named after its author, Xun Kuang, this philosophical text famously asserts that human nature is detestable.
Han Feizi
Written by Han Fei, this book covers diplomacy, war, economics, and administration, and it is said to have greatly influenced Qin Shi Huang, the first emperor of China.
Book of Origins
This book contains imperial genealogies connecting people living during the Spring and Autumn period to the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors.
Six Secret Teachings
Supposedly written by Lü Shang, this book covers the topic of warfare, specifically that related to overthrowing a ruling dynasty.
Three Strategies of Huang Shigong
Written by a Taoist hermit named Huang Shigong, this book supposedly let Zhang Liang transform into an adept statesman and war theorist.
Rites of Zhou
Originally known as Officers of Zhou, this book deals with organizational theory and bureaucracy and is considered a Confucian classic.
Analects
This book contains many sayings and ideas attributed to Confucius and his contemporaries, and is believed to have been written by Confucius' followers.
Records of the Grand Historian

Written by Sima Qian, this book covers two and a half millennia of history between the time of the Yellow Emperor and the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, and is considered a model for later dynastic histories.
Erya
This ancient book is considered the oldest surviving Chinese dictionary.
Classic of Mountains and Seas
This text is a compilation of various locations and beasts that likely are mythological in nature.
Book of Han
Composed by Ban Gu with the help of his sister Ban Zhao and notes left by their father Ban Biao, this book covers the history of the Western Han dynasty.
Weilüe
This record of the history of Wei is not considered an official history, and its claims regarding Roman elites and Parthian nobles are rather questionable.
Records of the Three Kingdoms
Written by Chen Shou, a Jin dynasty scholar, this work concerns itself with the histories of the Three Kingdoms.
Chronicles of Huayang
This text concerns itself with the history and geography of Huayang, and also contains biographies for some notable individuals from the area.
A New Account of the Tales of the World
Compiled and edited by Liu Yiqing, this is a compilation of many Chinese scholars, musicians, and artists that lived during the Han, Wei, and Jin dynasties.
Book of the Later Han
Written by Fan Ye and others, this work concerns itself with the Later, or Eastern, Han dynasty.
Sunzi Suanjing
Though its author is unknown, this book is perhaps of some interest for those with a scholarly interest in mathematics.
Book of Song
Written by Shen Yue, this work covers the history of the Song dynasty, one of the Southern Dynasties.
Book of Southern Qi
Rather unusual for a history book covering a former Chinese dynasty, the Book of Southern Qi was written by Xia Zixian, grandson of Emperor Gao, the founder of Southern Qi.
Spring and Autumn Annals of the Sixteen Kingdoms
Written by Cui Hong, this biographial history of the Sixteen Kingdoms is sadly somewhat incomplete.
Spring and Autumn Annals of the Sixteen Kingdoms
Rediscovered after being lost for centuries, this complete edition of the Spring and Autumn Annals of the Sixteen Kingdoms is certainly a literary masterpiece.
Classic of Go
If greedy, one will often be defeated. If timid, one will rarely succeed.
Book of Wei
Written by Wei Shou, this text covers the history of Northern and Eastern Wei.
Jingchu Suishiji
This book, once thought lost forever, details the history of many different festivals in the Jingchu region.
Book of Liang
Compiled by Yao Silian and partially based on the work of his father Yao Cha, this book notably covers both the Liang dynasty and countries to the east, such as Wa and fabled Fusang.
Book of Chen
Compiled by Yao Silian and partially based on notes left by his father Yao Cha, this history book is comparatively brief.
Book of Northern Qi
Li Baiyou's work has been partially lost, with only seventeen of the original fifty chapters remaining.
Book of Zhou
Composed by Linghu Defen, this work has sometimes been criticised by scholars like Liu Zhiji for its supposed attempts to glorify the ancestors of Tang officials.
Book of Jin
Many authors contributed to this work under the editorial oversight of Fang Xuanling. It covers both the Jin dynasty and the Sixteen Kingdoms.
Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Li Weigong
This dialogue covers matters of military strategy, discussing the merits of earlier theories and contrasting them with the author's own experience on the battlefield.
Book of Sui

Written by Yang Shigu, Kong Yingda, and Zhangsun Wuji, along with lead author Wei Zheng, this book covers the Sui dynasty, which was the first dynasty to reunite all of China since the Upheaval of the Five Barbarians.
History of the Southern Dynasties
Started by Li Daishi and completed by his son Li Yanshou, this book covers the Song, Southern Qi, Liang, and Chen dynasties.
History of the Northern Dynasties
Started by Li Daishi and completed by his son Li Yanshou, this book covers the Northern Wei, Western Wei, Eastern Wei, Northern Zhou, Northern Qi, and Sui dynasties.
Generality of Historiography

This book was written by Liu Zhiji and describes the general pattern of past offficial dynastic historiography, covering subjects such as structure, method, order of arrangement, sequence, caption, and commentary.
Treatise on Astrology of the Kaiyuan Era
This work notably contains a translation of the Indian Navagraha calendar.
The Classic of Tea
Written by Lu Yu, this monograph is of great use for anyone wishing to understand how to prepare tea in a proper, civilized fashion.
Comprehensive Institutions
Written by Du You, this book covers Chinese institutional history from early history to the reign of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang.
Old Book of Tang

Written by Zhang Zao, Jia Wei, and Zhao Xi, and edited by Liu Xu and Zhao Ying, this book has been severely criticised, with Emperor Renzong of Song calling it "poorly organized, burdened with unimportant details, wanting in style, and poorly researched".
History of the Five Dynasties
Compiled by Xue Juzheng, this book argues that the Five Dynasties possessed the Mandate of Heaven at various times, which makes it clear that the Song dynasty inherited it from them.
Historical Records of the Five Dynasties
Written by Ouyang Xiu, this book is considered more analytical than Xue Juzheng's History of the Five Dynasties.
Extensive Records of the Taiping Era
This manuscript was compiled by Li Fang but remains unpublished, seeing as it is regarded to be of no use to young students.
Institutions of the Five Dynasties Period
Written by Wang Pu, who personally served Later Han and Later Zhou, this book covers the government systems of the chaotic Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period.
Readings of the Taiping Era
Divided into a thousand volumes, this massive work was compiled under the oversight of Li Fang. Emperor Taizong of Song reportedly read all of it in a single year.
Finest Blossoms in the Garden of Literature
Compiled by a team of scholars under Li Fang, this anthology of poetry, odes, songs, and writings was not published for over two centuries.
Universal Geography of the Taiping Era
Written by the scholar Yue Shi, this book covers nearly all areas of China as they were around the time of its publication.
Models from the Archives
Named by Emperor Zhenzong of Song, this book was contributed to by many authors, including Wang Qinruo and Yang Yi.
Records of the Nine Kingdoms
This book by Lu Zhen covers nine of the Ten Kingdoms, leaving out Jingnan.
Wujing Zongyao

Authored by Zeng Gongliang, Ding Du, and Yang Weide, and with a foreword by Emperor Renzong of Song, this book covers a wide range of subjects, such as naval warships, types of catapults, and various incendiary weapons.
Book of Tang
Compiled by a team of scholars led by Ouyang Xiu and Song Qi, this book is meant as a replacement for the Old Book of Tang.
Comprehensive Mirror in Aid of Governance
Written by Sima Guang and others, this book was commissioned by Emperor Yingzong of Song and covers a period of almost fourteen centuries.
Dream Pool Essays
Written by Shen Kuo while living in forced retirement, this book covers a great number of topics, including but not limited to medicine, astronomy, and optics.
Treatise on Tea
This book about tea and tea competitions has the distinction of being written by the emperor himself during the Daguan Era of the Song dynasty.
Records of Rumors from Sushui
Written by Sima Guang, this is a collection of various anecdotes.
Summary of Events in the Eastern Capital
Written by Wang Cheng based on information compiled by his father Wang Shang, this book covers the Song dynasty prior to the Jingkang Incident.
Huang Song Shichao Gangyao
Written by Li Zhi, this book covers the Song dynasty up to the reign of Emperor Gaozong.
A Description of Barbarian Nations
Written by Zhao Rukuo, this book can perhaps be of some use when interacting with various barbarian cultures.
Records of the Khitan Stele
Written by Ye Longli, this book is full of superstition.
Hei An Zhuan
The Epic of Darkness is a collection of tales and legends about the creation of the world, from the birth of Pangu to the historical era.
Page from The Art of War

This is a single page from the Sun Tzu's famous book on military strategy, The Art of War. Although it is less useful than a complete copy of the book, the wisdom contained on this single page is still worth heeding.
Auspicious Tantra of All-Reaching Union
This multi-volume work translates an unknown Tantric Buddhist text into the Tangut language.
Bamboo Annals
Written on slips, this ancient record stretches from the age of the Yellow Emperor to the Warring States.
Lessons for Women
Written by Ban Zhao during the Han dynasty, this book outlines the four virtues a woman must abide by.
Women's Analects
Written by Song Ruoshen and Song Ruozhao, two of the Five Song Sisters, this book uses examples relevant to everyday life to illustrate proper female behavior.
Collection of New Songs from the Jade Lake
Edited by Cai Xingfeng, this collection of poetry exclusively draws from the works of female poets.
Eighteen Songs of a Nomad Flute
Composed by Liu Shang, these songs and poems depict the life of the Han dynasty poet Cai Wenji.
Daozang
This large canon of Taoist texts was assembled by monks seeking to bring together a number of disparate teachings.
Zhong He Ji
The Book of Balance and Harmony was created by the Taoist master Li Daochun. It outlines the teachings and practices of the Quanzhen School.
Huangdi Neijing
The Inner Canon of the Yellow Emperor is an ancient Chinese medical text that many consider the foundation of Chinese medicine.
Shennong Bencaojing
The Classic of the Materia Medica, attributed to Shennong, contains useful information about agriculture and medicinal plants.
Wushi'er Bingfang
The Receipts for Fifty-Two Ailments is believed to date from the Qin dynasty. It presents more than two hundred and fifty cures for a number of ailments.
Zhouyi Cantong Qi
Composed by Wei Boyang, The Kinship of the Three, in Accordance with the Book of Changes is considered the oldest book of Chinese alchemy.
Baopuzi
The Master Who Embraces Simplicity is a Chinese book covering everything from alchemy to literature to deomonolgy, written by Ge Hong.
Danjing Yaojue
The "Essential Formulas of Alchemical Classics" is a famous book of Chinese alchemy, attributed to the physician Sun Simiao.
Hongbao Yuanbi Shu
The "Arts from the Garden of Secrets of the Great Treasure" is a famous book of Chinese alchemy, supposedly containing both the secrets of immortality and the secrets of creating gold.
Zangshu
The "Book of Burial" is a commentary on the lost Classic of Burial written by the Taoist mystic Guo Pu. It helped influence the development of Feng Shui.
The Tale of Genji
A classic work of Japanese literature, penned by Murasaki Shikibu.
The Pillow Book
Written by Sei Shonagon, a court lady serving Empress Teishi, this book contains various observations and thoughts by its author.
The Tale of the Heike
Written at some point after the Genpei War, this is the story of this epic struggle between the Taira (Heike) and Minamoto (Genji) clans.
Ishinpo
This medical text was completed by Tamba Yasuyori and partially inspired by earlier work from China.
Hwarang Segi
Compiled by the Silla historian Gim Daemun, this record contains the early history of the Hwarang and the biographies of fifteen of its early leaders.
Samguk Sagi
Compiled by Gim Busik, a Goryeo official and historian, this record contains the history of the Three Kingdoms of Korea: Goguryeo, Baekje, and Silla.
Samguk Yusa
Compiled by the monk Iryeon, this record contains legends, folktales, and historical accounts about the Three Kingdoms of Korea: Goguryeo, Baekje, and Silla.
Haedong Goseungjeon
Compiled by the monk Gakhun, this record contains information about the lives of several important monks from the Three Kingdoms period in Korean history.
Jewang Un'gi
This poem was composed by Yi Seunghyu and consists of two volumes. It depicts the history of Korea from Dangun to the time when it was written.
The Great Dharani Sutra
This copy of the Usnisa Vijaya Dharani Sutra was discovered in Seokgatap, the three-storied pagoda at Bulguksa and is considered the oldest printed text in the world.
A Beginner's Guide to Isolationism
This book contains some information on the subject of having a foreign policy based around isolationism.
Keeping Your Head
A guide about Japanese etiquette, useful if you want to avoid an early grave.
The Tale of a Dynasty
A fictional account of the life of a fictional member of an influential dynasty.
The Tale of [foreigners_host.GetOnlyDynastyName]
A fictional account of the life of a fictional member of the influential [foreigners_host.GetOnlyDynastyName] dynasty.
They Have Curved Swords
Curved. Swords.
Katanas Are Just Better
A book about the one kind of sword that clearly is better than all others.
Warriors of the Rising Sun
A book about the fighting techniques employed by several famous warriors from Japan.
Cherry Blossoms are Pretty
A book about the author's obsession with cherry blossoms.
Bureaucracy for Fools
Some small tips regarding dealing with bureaucratic matters, including example forms in triplicate.
The Provinces of a Realm
A book detailing what can be found in various provinces in a realm.
The Provinces of [foreigners_host.PrimaryTitle.GetBaseName]
A book detailing what can be found in the various provinces of [foreigners_host.PrimaryTitle.GetBaseName].
The Highly Visible Ninja
A book concerning a failed assassination attempt by an unskilled assassin.
How To Wall Climb
A book about various athletic exercies one can engage in to become and stay healthy.
Conservation of Ninjutsu
A book containing information about why sending one skilled assassin can be better than sending an army of them.
How To Haiku
This is a small book\nabout writing a haiku.\nIt might be useful.
Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji
A book about various Japanese writing systems.
The Complete History of a Realm
A most thorough account of the history of a realm.
The [foreigner_origin_province.Capital.GetName] History of [foreigners_host.PrimaryTitle.GetBaseName]
An account of the history of [foreigners_host.PrimaryTitle.GetBaseName], spanning multiple centuries.
The Works of Shan Yu
Are you familiar with the works of Shan Yu?
Ganjiang
Forged by the swordsmith couple Gan Jiang and Mo Ye during the Spring and Autumn Period, the swords named after the couple were supposedly involved in the death of King Helü of Wu.
Moye
Forged by the swordsmith couple Gan Jiang and Mo Ye during the Spring and Autumn Period, the swords named after the couple were supposedly involved in the death of King Helü of Wu.
Sword of Goujian
This sword once belonged to King Goujian of Yue, the arch-rival of King Fuchai of Wu.
Spear of Fuchai
This sword once belonged to King Fuchai of Wu, the arch-rival of King Goujian of Yue.
Green Dragon Crescent Blade
The Green Dragon Crescent Blade, or Frost Fair Blade, was supposedly wielded by the legendary Chinese general Guan Yu during the Three Kingdoms period.
Dragon-Phoenix Sword
The Dragon-Phoenix Sword is the legendary blade of King Zi Shou of Shou. He supposedly handed it out to some of his subjects to let them enforce his will.
Zhanlu
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Zhao of Chu.
Juque
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Zhao of Chu.
Shengxie
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Zhao of Chu.
Yuchang
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Zhao of Chu.
Chunjun
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Zhao of Chu.
Longyuan
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Goujian of Yue.
Tai'e
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Goujian of Yue.
Gongbu
This sword was forged by the legendary Chinese sword-maker Ou Yezi for King Goujian of Yue.
Totsuka no Tsurugi

Totsuka no Tsurugi ("Sword of Length of Ten Fists") is not a specific sword, but rather a kind of sword wielded by several deities in Japanese mythology. Now, one of those swords rests in mortal hands.
Kojiki
Composed by O no Yatsumaro at the request of Empress Genmei, the Kojiki ("Records of Ancient Matters" or "An Account of Ancient Matters") details the origin of the Japanese archipelago and the kami.
Nihon Shoki

Written under the editorial supervision of Prince Toneri and O no Yatsumaro and dedicated to Empress Genmei, the Nihon Shoki ("The Chronicles of Japan") showcases the merits of virtuous rulers and the errors of bad ones.
Kogarasu Maru
Believed to have been created by the legendary weaponsmith Amakuni, Kogarasu Maru ("Little Crow") is a unique tachi.
Dojigiri
Dojigiri ("Slayer of Shuten-doji") is one of the Tenka-Goken (the "Five (Best) Swords under Heaven"). It was forged by Hoki-no-Kuni Yasutsuna.
Onimaru
Onimaru ("Demon") is one of the Tenka-Goken (the "Five (Best) Swords under Heaven"). It was forged by Awataguchi Sakon-no-Shogen Kunitsuna.
Mikazuki
Mikazuki ("Crescent Moon") is one of the Tenka-Goken (the "Five (Best) Swords under Heaven"). It was forged by Sanjo Kokaji Munechika.
Odenta
Odenta ("Great Denta", or "The Best among Swords Forged by Denta") is one of the Tenka-Goken (the "Five (Best) Swords under Heaven"). It was forged by Miike Denta Mitsuyo.
Juzumaru
Juzumaru ("Rosary") is one of the Tenka-Goken (the "Five (Best) Swords under Heaven"). It was forged by Aoe Tsunetsugu.
Thuan Thien

The blade of Thuan Thien ("Heaven's Will") was supposedly discovered in a lake by a fisherman, while the hilt was found in a banyan tree. Together, the two form a mighty weapon, but perhaps not a weapon you should keep for too long...
Hilt of Thuan Thien

This is the hilt of a most fascinating sword named Thuan Thien ("Heaven's Will"), found inside the trunk of a banyan tree. It appears to emit a slight glow. If the blade can be found, the sword should be possible to restore...
Blade of Thuan Thien

This is the blade of a most fascinating sword named Thuan Thien ("Heaven's Will"), discovered in a lake by a fisherman. It appears to emit a slight glow. If the hilt can be found, the sword should be possible to restore...
Vijaya
The bow Vijaya ("Victory") once belonged to the legendary Karna, the King of Anga. It was gifted to him by his teacher Parasurama, who in turn got it from Shiva himself.
Gram
Not for use against Fafnir! - Vlad (not a vampire!)
Incomplete Deck of Cards
Maybe you should pull out a card or three. What is the worst thing that could happen?
Wandy the Talking Wand
It seems like you are trying to cast a spell. Would you like some help with that?
Book of Burninating
A guide to how to terrorize the countryside properly
This item can only be used by dragons
This book contains nothing you do not already know.
Shiny Bauble
So shiny!
Broken Dragon Egg
The dragon is long gone
Fantastic Map
You have never heard of the "Citadel of Certain Doom" before, and the other landmarks are equally unfamiliar.
Princess Doll
Kidnapped from her family by the fearsome dragon Fredak, the Emperor of Embers.
Hammer of Banishment
Legends say that when trolls ran rampant in the forums of the Roman Empire the Moderatorii were there to fight them.
This item can only be used by moderators
The +1 Ring
+1 Ring to rule them all, +1 Ring to find them, +1 Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them
Draught of Healing
This strange red liquid can be used to heal injuries, cure diseases, or improve your health.
Dragonscale Shield
Created from a scale from the mighty Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, this shield is impervious to normal weapons.
Sword of Two Minds
Kill them all! "No, help them all!" "Kill them!" "Help them!"
Draconic Lineages
It seems Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, had an impressive family tree.
Ornate Holy Symbol
This is a symbol of faith that is more impressive than most
Prestigious Ring
There is just something about this ring that says "I am noteworthy!"
Sanity's Demise
I know such secrets! Shall I share them with you?
Vial of Immortality
By consuming the glowing liquid inside you will obtain eternal life.
Living Flame
BURN THEM ALL!
Hungering Blade
FEED ME!
Deed to the Dragon Throne
Just scratch out "Fredak, the Emperor of Embers" and put your own name on it.
Silver Ring of the Tongue
This ring grants mastery of all matters pertaining to speechcraft.
Steel Band of the Warrior's Might
This ring grants mastery of all matters pertaining to war.
Golden Ring of Avarice
This ring grants mastery of all matters pertaining to wealth.
Sinister Ring of Shadows
This ring grants mastery of all matters pertaining to secrecy.
Ring of Many Metals
This ring grants mastery of all matters pertaining to knowledge.
Lost Eagle of the Lost Legion
Whether Fredak, the Emperor of Embers, destroyed the legion this eagle once belonged to or merely stole it from somewhere is a mystery for the ages.
Dao
A well crafted sword.
Dadao
A sword crafted by a grandmaster.
The Celestial Blade
A high quality sword, known as the Celestial Blade. Some say divine inspiration was behind its creation.
The Balanced Blade
Forged with the finest steel available, this sword appears to be particularly well balanced, which doubtlessly makes it deadly in the right hands.
The Heavenly Sword
A great and magnificent sword known as the Heavenly Sword, it is said to bring good fortune to any who wields it.
The Celestial Dragon's Blade
A legendary blade, said to have been personally blessed by a celestial dragon during its creation.
The Blade of Harmonous Balance
A legendary blade. Perfectly balanced, as all things should be.
The Sword of the Heavens' Command
A legendary blade, said to make even poor soldiers capable of following through on the commands of its wielder.
Tachi
A well crafted sword.
Odachi
A sword crafted by a grandmaster.
The Rising Sun
Forged with the finest steel available, this blade has a particularly beautiful sheen, and is also quite sharp.
The Dragon
A great and magnificent sword known as the Dragon, supposedly as a reference to the terrible wounds it is capable of inflicting in the hands of a skilled wielder.
Honor
A high quality sword, known as Honor. Its wielder is sure to be reminded to act in an honorable fashion, even on the battlefield.
The Katana of the Rising Sun
A legendary blade, said to embody the noble spirit of the warriors of the land of the Rising Sun.
The Blade of the Dragon
A legendary blade, said to be calable of turning any wielder into a threat that cannot be ignored.
The Honor of the Samurai
A legendary sword, named to remind its wielder and all who follow them to act with honor in all things.
Khanda
A well crafted sword.
Talwar
A sword crafted by a grandmaster.
Destroyer
Forged with the finest steel available, this blade is supposed to be able to pierce any armor and shatter any weapon facing it if wielded properly.
Retribution
A high quality sword, known as Retribution. Those that have wronger its wielder should be particularly weary in their presence.
Wrath
A great and magnificent sword known as Wrath, said to be well suited for an aggressive wielder.
The Bringer of Destruction
A legendary sword, said to have been blessed by Shiva to bring destruction to all that would oppose its wielder.
Karmic Retribution
A legendary blade, said to be particularly well suited for punishing those that have wronged its wielder.
Divine Wrath
A legendary blade, said to be blessed with the power to make its wielder cut through any opposition.
Grand Sapanpe
Made of bones carved into the likeness of the sacred bears, this crown is truly fit for the temporal representative of the kamuy.
Scepter of the Sacred Flame
Said to have gifted the Andamanese people with fire, this scepter is the one true symbol of the head of the faith.
Jade Seal of the Benzhu
Carved out of sacred jade, this seal may only be used by the temporal representative of the Benzhu.
The Necklace of the Nats
This sacred amulet was gifted to the first Great Nat Kadaw by the Nats themselves.
Tarombo Scepter
This ivory scepter bears a carving of the entire family history of the Pemena's temporal head.
The Celestial Seal
Carved out of sacred jade, this seal is said to surpass even the Heirloom Seal of the Realm.
Spear of Balance
This spear and its three branches represent the upper world, the afterlife, and the mortal life of all humans, and the need to always strive for balance.
Sacred Gayang
This ornate sword is the symbol of the Grand Bobohizan's authority.
The Mascapaicha
This crown confers the divine authority of Inti upon its wearer.
The Sky-Given Crown
Said to have been forged from the metal of a fallen star, this crown confers the divine authority of [jurchen_pagan_reformed.GetHighGodName] upon its wearer.
Reforged Crown of Chumo
This crow is said to be the equal of the long-lost crown of King Chumo, also known as Dongmyeongseongwang.
Blessed Crown of the Anito
This crown is said to carry the blessing of all the Anito.
The Scepter of the Seas
This scepter is said to confer authority over all the seas to its wearer.
Bow of Yaj Yuam
Said to be the bow of Yaj Yuam, the Heavenly Archer, this bow is no longer used for combat but instead as a symbol of the Keb Dab Qhuas faith.
Santi of the Spirits
This santi is said to have been blessed by the spirits.
Holy Karaambit
This karaambit has been blessed by all the priests of the Minangkabau faith.
Sacred Bear Talisman
This talisman confers both authority and protection upon its wearer.
The Sword of Amamikyu
This sword was bestowed upon the first Chifi-Ufujin by Amamikyu herself, proving their divine authority.
Amulet of the Golden Python
This amulet may only be worn by the temporal head of the Sanamahi faith.
Golden Trishula
This trident is the one true symbol of temporal authority for the Sunda Wiwitan faithful.
Sacred Makuta
The crown of the Great Mophi is said to confer a number of blessings upon its wearer.
Holy Jade Crown
This jade crown is seen as a symbol of the Taiwanese faith.
The Heavenly Sword
This sacred sword is believed to have conferred supreme temporal authority upon its wielder.
Seal of Zhyge Alu
Carved out of sacred jade, this seal is said to once have belonged to Zhyge Alu, the hero of old.
Scepter of the Three Elements
This scepter bestows authority over the sky, over the earth, and over the water, and thus over the world.
